Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Debugging Smart Cyberphysical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is based on two trends: (a) software is quickly becoming the most complex and expensive part of engineering products like cars, medical devices, and drones and (b) existing testing and simulation techniques are inadequate for finding software bugs in early design. This leads to expensive recalls and sometimes fatal failures, and increasingly, certification bodies are incorporating stringent testing and verification standards. Successful completion of this project will result in a scalable prototype tool that will help demonstrate to our potential customers, namely the engineering system designer, that it is possible to radically cut down software development cost without compromising on quality. This will be possible using our algorithms and tools that enable effective early discovery of bugs as well as coverage guarantees that give certificates for meeting design requirements.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop commercial technology that can scalably analyze the correctness of designs. The software tool built in this project will automatically check the safety of system designs by combining fast numerical simulations, with automatic analysis of design models to cover a large set of possible behaviors from a few traces. Our techniques have had demonstrable success on several industry-scale challenge problems in the automotive, avionics, and medical devices industries. In this project, we will develop a polished prototype of our software tool with features that will enhance the designer's experience. It will provide automated support for debugging complex system designs. These features will flatten the learning curve for the tool and make the approach applicable to existing industry standard design environments like Simulink/Stateflow. We will develop use-cases for the tool that will demonstrate the entire design workflow on challenging problems. The prototype and the use cases will become the basis for the creation of a minimum viable product and for beta testing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid growth in computing, communication, and sensing technologies is driving the growth of “smart” engineering systems. In the automotive sector, for example, more than 80\% of new features are based on software that combine these technologies towards annual model updates offering better electrification, connectivity, fuel efficiency, driving experience, and importantly---safety. The growth trends in emerging sectors such as UAVs, IoT, and medical devices are just as strong.

A major part of product development cost for these systems is attributed to testing, verification, and validation (V&V in short). The market pull for new features undercuts the goal for ensuring and improving safety. Current testing, verification and validation (V&V in short) technologies were created for hardware and software systems that manipulate bits, and they are unsuitable and inadequate for these cyberphysical systems where bits tightly interact with physical quantities like time, velocities, and thrusts. Thus, design bugs often remain hidden during early stages, and only surface later or even after the product is sold, resulting in costly redesigns, recalls, and accidents.

Current V&V is essentially based on extensive simulations and tests either in silico or in a physical test environment. The limits of these approaches can be best understood through an example. Imagine an automotive control system for automatic left lane passing. The system has to be tested with respect to many uncertain parameters, e.g., the speed and the distance between the cars, timing of the maneuver, road friction, behavior of the drivers, etc. To ensure safety and reliability, one needs to not only test all these parameters, but also analyze the behavior of the design under sensor failures and environmental hazards.

Testing alone cannot account for all of these possibilities. Even for a single parameter like the initial relative position of the two cars, simulations and testing can only cover finitely many possibilities, but in reality there are uncountably infinite possibilities, each of which could lead to dramatically different future behaviors. Indeed, after the feature is released, when millions of people use the designed system, over thousands of hours, the untested scenarios will almost surely materialize and lead to accidents. Thus, simulations and tests alone are recognized to be inadequate for variations in even a small number of uncertain parameters.

Our core V&V technology exploits the inherent continuity of physical processes with respect to uncertain parameters (e.g. position of cars, relative speeds, road friction, etc.). Continuity is the property that says that small changes in the initial position (respectively speed, friction, etc.) of the cars will only cause bounded changes in the relative positions in the near future. We have developed effective algorithms for computing these bounded changes, and thus, from a single test or simulation our tool can infer all the behaviors of the system that can arise when the uncertain parameters are changed by some amount. As part of the Phase I SBIR project, we have built a software analysis tool C2E2 that automatically analyzes both white-box and black-box models of nonlinear cyberphysical systems, to either find bugs in the design or to construct a proof of correctness. Case studies performed as part of the project demonstrate the effectiveness of the method and commercial potential of the technology.
